Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing Course Modules to Teach Service-Oriented Programming through Exemplification and Visualization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Service oriented programming (SOP) is a programming technique to build software applications using services provided on the web as the building blocks. With cloud computing and mobile devices becoming ubiquitous, SOP is becoming even more crucial, but has not made significant inroads into the U.S. undergraduate computing curricula. This project represents a well-conceived effort to address this shortcoming by developing coursework in SOP to ensure that U.S. students are prepared in this crucial technology, thus competitive in the global software development marketplace.

This project is being jointly conducted at three diverse participating institutions: Howard University in Washington, DC, the State University of New York at Oswego, and the Rochester Institute of Technology in Rochester, NY. Three reusable curricular modules in SOP are being designed for different undergraduate computing courses - a first year introductory programming course, a sophomore course, and a senior-level course. These curricular materials are being constructed on a carefully crafted platform that provides examples and visualization to help achieve effective learning. A modular approach is being used to ensure that the developed curricular materials will be useful for a variety of undergraduate institutions across the United States. Project results are being broadly disseminated through various channels, including regional and national workshops, institutional websites and the National STEM Distributed Learning Resource Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. We designed, developed, and refined the proposed course modules, including the presentation slides, lab assignments, and quiz questions.
  2. We designed and developed approximately 35 web services and 15 SOP applications using various programming techniques and across various domains. The services and applications were used to exemplify the fundamental concepts and technology of SOP.
  3. We designed and developed a visualization interface that enables students to visualize the development process and helps them learn SOP concepts and technologies.
  4. We used a virtualization software package, Oracle VM Virtual Box, to encapsulate the development environment, including the operating system (Ubuntu), development platform (Netbeans), and Web Server (Glassfish), as well as a sample project, into a virtual machine. This makes the lab environment setup easy and convenient. This also saves significant trouble of configuring development environment and facilitates the adoption of our course material. The VM only includes open source software to avoid any potential copyright issue.
  5. 72 students were taught SOP in their programming classes. Many of them expressed their interests in the topic through the survey.
  6. We received positive feedback from the faculty attendees of our SOP workshops. Most of them have expressed great interests of using our course material. They could see themselves teaching the topics when the schedule allows and by working closely with us for further support.
  7. We published and presented three papers, one work in progress, two full papers, at three major education or research conferences in the community, including FIE 2013, ICSOC 2015, and ASEE 2016.
  8. We hosted workshops at two major Computer Science education conferences, FIE 2013 and SIGCSE 2014 to disseminate our work to national participants.
  9. We offered two regional summer workshops, one at RIT in 2013 and one at Howard University in 2014, to disseminate our work to local participants. The workshops were well attended by the instructors from two-year colleges and HBCUs.
